Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: The CyberPhyscial Challenges of Transient Stability and Security in Power Grids

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The national transmission networks that deliver high voltage electric power underpin our society and are central to the ongoing transformation of the American energy infrastructure. Transmission networks are very large and complicated engineering systems, and "keeping the lights on" as the transformation of the American energy infrastructure proceeds is a fundamental engineering challenge involving both the physical aspects of the equipment and the cyber aspects of the controls, communications, and computers that run the system. The project develops new principles of cyber-physical engineering by focusing on instabilities of electric power networks that can cause blackouts. It proposes novel approaches to analyze these instabilities and to design cyber-physical control methods to monitor, detect, and mitigate them. The controls must perform robustly in the presence of variability and uncertainty in electric generation, loads, communications, and equipment status, and during abnormal states caused by natural faults or malicious attacks.

The research produces cyber-physical engineering methodologies that specifically help to mitigate power system blackouts and more generally show the way forward in designing robust cyber-physical systems in environments characterized by rich dynamics and uncertainty. Education and outreach efforts involve students at high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels, as well as dissemination of results to the public and the engineering and applied science communities in industry, government and universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Power transmission networks are the underpinnings of our way of life. Driven by the growth of renewable energy sources, along with the availability of a fine grained real time information infrastructure power networks, are at the center of the transformation of the US energy system. “Keeping the lights on” as we transform an already large and complicated power system is a fundamental challenge for cyber-physical engineering. To develop new principles that integrate physical and cyber aspects into a unified theory, we focused on the problem of detecting and avoiding fast instabilities of power networks that can cause blackouts. We proposed novel approaches to analyze these dynamic instabilities and to design cyber-physical control methods to mitigate them. The controls must perform robustly in the presence of variability and uncertainty in generation, loads, communications, and operating state, and during abnormal states caused by natural faults or malicious attacks. 

Trustworthiness of sensor data is essential to the safe operation of the grid. A malicious agent may launch stealthy integrity attacks on sensors to disorient system operator and leading them to make wrong operational decisions, thus letting the system drive itself to undesirable and possibly dangerous operating points without exerting any physical perturbation and without being detected. This is one of the easiest and less costly way to attack a system, and can be carried out remotely. Stuxnet is the quintessential living example of the potential of data attacks on physical systems. We proposed to adopt both passive and active methods of detection of compromised data. Passive methods used the measurement of the discrepancy between the system’s predicted behavior and its measurements. Active methods comprised the injection of random perturbations into systems and detecting their effect at the sensor side, e.g. physical watermarking. Such method, while particularly effective, needs to be designed carefully as not to have negative effects on the system’s operation. We proposed to develop policies that adaptively pick perturbations, in order to monitor the system dynamically, based on suspicious sensor activity and to eliminate the possibility of inducing harmful perturbations.
